Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Predictive Technology for Failure Prevention of Industrial Machinery
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed study focuses on the commercialization of predictive technology for failure prevention of industrial machinery. The commercialization of this technology has the potential to represent a significant development that will be leveraging years of scientific and engineering research in the area of Prognostics and Health Management (PHM). The enhanced reconfigurable and modularized software platform is an important step for achieving the goal of rapid and low-cost solutions for predicting and preventing failures in industrial machinery.

The scope of the proposed effort during the I-Corps study addresses a significant need expressed by industry for having a commercialized solution for predictive maintenance. The successful demonstration during previous projects showed the feasibility of the technology. However, in order to demonstrate the full economic benefits regarding cost, asset availability, and downtime reduction that industry desires, the technology must be cast in a form that can be more easily deployed and implemented. Successful implementation of this technology in manufacturing facilities has the potential to result in lower cost and higher quality products, thus providing a benefit to the end users of the manufactured goods. In addition, manufactures who implement this technology will likely have a competitive advantage in the market place due to the higher quality and productivity they could achieve by preventing costly equipment failures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During NSF I-Corps program, the National Science Foundation (NSF) Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) formed the team to commercialize the predictive technology IMS center developed in past ten years.  Through program course study, attending industry conference, and engaging with potential industry customers and investors, a rough business model for commercializing the technology has been formulated.

The main technology resides in the reconfigurable software algorithms which is used to recognize impending machine  health problems and initiate actions before they lead to major downtime or productivity loss. The team's vision is to enable a machine to assess its health for self-maintenance and order its own parts (Lessons Learned Video: http://youtu.be/allyqtMVhEI, Technical Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPC-0PEtFfU).

After investigation, the team finds out there is a large market size for the potential predictive technology  including 88 USA Automotive Plants, Aerospace Manufacturing, 1522 Coal Power Plants , 104 Nuclear Power Plants, 5600 Chemical Processing Plants, 50,000MW Wind Turbines, 5635 units Gas Turbine Power Generation. Particularly, automotive manufacturing sites have 500-8000 industrial robots, if assuming a lower bound estimation of 30 per site. Furthermore, if we reached 1000 of these customers and $10K for each predictive monitoring solution, this would provide a total market of $300 Million. The above estimation only includes top three customer segments and not the ones from mining industry or semiconductor manufacturing that are included in our business canvas (Figure 1 ) or the other ones that we could add as the company grows.

Feedback summary shows that as we focused more, we obtained more positive customer discovery results and more validated hypotheses of business model design. Top segments of customers (Table 1) are from automotive manufacturing, power plants or energy, aerospace manufacturing, Mining Equipment and semiconductor manufacturing. The team visits 72 potential customers, exactly 50% of the total meetings were in person (36 and 36). Business channels is designed based on machine product end user and OEM. Revenue stream is expected to come from selling the product as a standalone system, integrating it with existing monitoring system, providing consulting or training service and software licensing. The team also identified strategic, investment, and supplier partners.

The new start-up company, Predictronics, is basically formulated legally, which registered as Ohio C level business corporation. Predictronics has approached two potential customers. One is undermining equipment manufacturer; another is automotive manufacturer. The team has submitted proposed solutions to customers for further technical and financial evaluations. Predictronics has been contacting with one potential investor from Japan and received positive response. The team has been preparing the legal documents with University of Cincinnati for licensing the technology.

 


Last Modified: 01/06/2013
Modified by: Jay Lee
